scenes.title: Three-front war, one new lever
scenes.main_point: AI raised expectations, broke distribution, and intensified competition; growth shifted to trust.
scenes.scene_summary: AI raised expectations, collapsed channels, and attacked value props—so growth shifted to trust.
key_elements: Three-front pressure: expectations, distribution collapse, value-prop attacks
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
A lone startup founder stands at a desk in a simple office, facing a wall board split into three labeled fronts: rising expectations, collapsed distribution channels, and value-prop attacks.
They place a single new lever labeled “trust” at the center, looking tense but determined.

scenes.title: Acquisition moved from channels to people
scenes.main_point: Traditional acquisition weakened; trust-based channels like employees, creators, community, and product experience worked.
scenes.scene_summary: SEO, SEM, and corporate social weakened; employees, creators, community, and product experience drove trust.
key_elements: SEO disrupted by AI content and answer engines
SEM costs rose as searches stagnated and AI tools competed
Corporate social throttled links and favored on-platform engagement
Employee-led social built transparency and human trust
Creator partnerships transferred trust when ICP fit was real
Community and word-of-mouth compounded; features copied, trust not
Product-led brand: every interaction built or reduced trust
Sponsor mention: Cello referral platform embedded in product
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
In the same war-room from scene 1, the same startup team stands around a table as a whiteboard shows fading icons for SEO/SEM/corporate social while brighter lines connect employees, creators, community, and product experience.
One teammate places a small “Cello” referral card into the product sketch, and the group looks focused and hopeful.

scenes.title: Retention became a trust moat
scenes.main_point: AI commoditized cost and efficiency value props; retention depended on confidence the team would keep delivering outcomes.
scenes.scene_summary: As AI commoditized utility, customers stayed with products they trusted to keep improving outcomes.
key_elements: Value prop buckets: cheaper, more efficient, more effective
AI outperformed many SaaS on speed and cost; $20/month pressure
Trust defined as confidence in ongoing better outcomes
Trust builders: real roadmap visibility, fast feedback iteration, WOW UX details
Lifecycle comms either built or reduced trust
Outcome-aligned monetization reduced churn and ‘sleeping bears’
Operational shift: break silos, optimize shipping velocity, build in public
Closing warning: channels and value props collapsed faster than expected
scenes.scene_prompt:
Delicate watercolor painting style, soft washes, visible brush strokes, muted tones.
In the same startup war-room, the founder and small team stand together at a whiteboard labeled “cheaper / more efficient / more effective,” drawing a protective moat around “TRUST = better outcomes.”
They pin up a simple public roadmap and a feedback loop arrow, calmly watching a “$20/mo” price tag drift away from their product icon, conveying resolved confidence.
